description: From Middle English fot, fote, foot, from Old English fōt, from Proto-West Germanic *fōt, from Proto-Germanic *fōts, from Proto-Indo-European *pṓds. Doublet of pes and pous.

nouns.description: foot (plural feet or (UK colloquial, unit of measure) foot)

entries.meaning: A biological structure found in many animals that is used for locomotion and that is frequently a separate organ at the terminal part of the leg.
(anatomy) Specifically, a human foot, which is found below the ankle and is used for standing and walking.
examples: Southern Italy is shaped like a foot.

entries.meaning: (often used attributively) Travel by walking.
examples: We went there by foot because we could not afford a taxi.
There is a lot of foot traffic on this street.

entries.meaning: The base or bottom of anything.
examples: I'll meet you at the foot of the stairs.

entries.meaning: The part of a flat surface on which the feet customarily rest.
examples: We came and stood at the foot of the bed.

entries.meaning: The end of a rectangular table opposite the head.
examples: The host should sit at the foot of the table.

entries.meaning: A short foot-like projection on the bottom of an object to support it.
examples: The feet of the stove hold it a safe distance above the floor.

entries.meaning: A unit of measure equal to twelve inches or one third of a yard, equal to exactly 30.48 centimetres.
examples: The flag pole at the local high school is about 20 feet high.

entries.meaning: (music) A unit of measure for organ pipes equal to the wavelength of two octaves above middle C, approximately 328 mm.
(collective, military) Foot soldiers; infantry.
examples: King John went to battle with ten thousand foot and one thousand horse.

entries.meaning: (cigars) The end of a cigar which is lit, and usually cut before lighting.
(sewing) The part of a sewing machine which presses downward on the fabric, and may also serve to move it forward.
(printing) The bottommost part of a typed or printed page.
(printing) The base of a piece of type, forming the sides of the groove.
(prosody) The basic measure of rhythm in a poem.
(phonology) The parsing of syllables into prosodic constituents, which are used to determine the placement of stress in languages along with the notions of constituent heads.
(nautical) The bottom edge of a sail.
examples: To make the mainsail fuller in shape, the outhaul is eased to reduce the tension on the foot of the sail.

entries.meaning: (billiards) The end of a billiard or pool table behind the foot point where the balls are racked.
(botany) In a bryophyte, that portion of a sporophyte which remains embedded within and attached to the parent gametophyte plant.
(malacology) The muscular part of a bivalve mollusc or a gastropod by which it moves or holds its position on a surface.
(molecular biology) The globular lower domain of a protein.
(geometry) The point of intersection of one line with another that is perpendicular to it.
Fundamental principle; basis; plan.
examples: Answer directly upon the foot of dry reason.

entries.meaning: Recognized condition; rank; footing.
examples: As to his being on the foot of a servant.

verbs.description: foot (third-person singular simple present foots, present participle footing, simple past and past participle footed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To use the foot to kick (usually a ball).
(transitive) To pay (a bill).
To tread to measure of music; to dance; to trip; to skip.
examples: There's time enough, I hope, To foot a measure with the bonnie bride,

entries.meaning: To walk.
(now rare) To set foot on; to walk on.
examples: People who would not have dared to foot the place before crept in and did not come to the house.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To set on foot; to establish; to land.
To renew the foot of (a stocking, etc.).
examples: I'll sew nether stocks and mend them and foot them too

entries.meaning: To sum up, as the numbers in a column; sometimes with up.
examples: to foot (or foot up) an account
